sentence.text: The subject was a male baby who was born after a full-term pregnancy.
His mother and father were 31 and 34 years of age, respectively, at the time of his birth.
The parents were not consanguineous.
The family history was not contributory.
There was no maternal illness or drug usage during pregnancy.
The pregnancy was uneventful until week 25 of gestation, when a cloverleaf skull was diagnosed by prenatal ultrasonography.
The infant weighed 2980 g and was 47 cm long at birth.
Clinical examination showed a cloverleaf skull caused by premature closure of multiple cranial sutures.
The skin overlying the scalp, face, ears, upper lips and limbs was markedly corrugated (Fig. 1a).
These deep furrows were vertically arranged.
The mid-facial region was hypoplastic with a small nose and depressed nasal bridge.
There was choanal stenosis that resulted in breathing difficulty.
The subject's eyes were proptotic.
Hypertelorism, downslanting palpebral fissures were also present.
The subject's ears were low set and malformed with deep vertical furrows in the pre-auricular area (Fig. 1b).
The oral cavity was small with a high, arched cleft palate.
The umbilical stump was large and protruded (Fig. 1c).
The corrugations were also present on the palms, soles and scrotal area (Fig. 1d).
Neither acanthosis nigricans nor chiari malformation were noticed.
Chromosomal analysis using the Giema-banding technique showed a normal 46,XY karyotype.
On admission to the present authors' neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), an oropharyngeal tube was put in place to facilitate breathing.
Nasogastric tube feeding was required because of poor sucking and easy choking.
There were also clear fluid discharges from the subject's nose.
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea was suspected.
A bifrontal suture craniectomy was performed, and the naso-ethmoid encephalocele was repaired by the anterior approach to prevent downward sliding of the encephalocele and CSF leakage.

A three-dimensional computerized tomography scan of the head done at birth showed no hydrocephalus (Fig. 2a), but markedly dilated ventricles with an obstructive hydrocephalus were revealed by 3 months of age and a V-P shunt was put in place at that time (Fig. 2b).
At one year of age, acanthosis nigricans was noted at the umbilical stump and inner upper thigh.
Arnold Chiari type II malformation was also noted at follow-up brain tomography.
A transfrontal orbital reconstruction and trans-oral LeFort I osteotomy and cranioplasty was performed.
This boy is now 3 years of age and can stand with aid.
The subject's body weight is 12 kg and his height is 91 cm.
